message_1: If p represents the statement "I have a pet cat" and q represents the statement "I have a pet dog", evaluate the truth value of the following proposition: "(p and q) or (not p and not q)".
message_2:
To evaluate the truth value of the proposition "(p and q) or (not p and not q)", we need to consider all possible combinations of truth values for p and q. There are four possible combinations:

1. p is true, q is true
2. p is true, q is false
3. p is false, q is true
4. p is false, q is false

Now, let's evaluate the proposition for each combination:

1. (p and q) or (not p and not q) = (True and True) or (not True and not True) = (True) or (False and False) = True
2. (p and q) or (not p and not q) = (True and False) or (not True and not False) = (False) or (False and True) = False
3. (p and q) or (not p and not q) = (False and True) or (not False and not True) = (False) or (True and False) = False
4. (p and q) or (not p and not q) = (False and False) or (not False and not False) = (False) or (True and True) = True

So, the proposition "(p and q) or (not p and not q)" is true when both p and q are true, or when both p and q are false. It is false when one of them is true and the other is false.
